numbered_ace_sentences: 1. I notice an extreme increase in the admission odds for legacy applicants.
2. I notice an increase in the admission odds for applicants whose parents are in the top 1% to 5% of income.
3. I notice no change in the admission odds based on income below the top 5%.
4. I notice that income has a much greater effect on admission odds for legacy applicants than for non-legacy applicants.
5. I wonder why there is a large difference between non-legacy applicants and legacy applicants.
6. A college should accept the best applicants.
7. A college should not accept applicants only because the parents attended the college.
8. I wonder why income affects admissions so greatly.
9. Applicants with higher income may have more support to build a better application.
10. Income may be part of the admissions calculations.
11. I wonder why income reduces the admission odds for non-legacy applicants until the top 5% of income.
12. I wonder why income increases the admission odds for legacy applicants.
13. Admission to college is very important to me.
14. Admission to college is very important to many other students in my community.
15. Most students in my community are not legacy applicants.
16. If non-legacy applicants have a great disadvantage, then the hopes of many students in my district will be damaged.
17. My district is split by the financial status of parents.
18. The financial status of parents should not affect admissions.
19. The most supported students are not often the smartest students.
20. The most supported students are not often the hardest working students.
21. The headline is: College Admissions Skewed: The Effects of Income and Legacy.
